2.content:
<Paldea>

Description:
- Based on Iberian Peninsula (Spain, Portugal, Andorra)
- Inspired by Spanish/Portuguese culture, architecture, food, music
- Locals occasionally use Spanish language
- No traditional routes; divided into 4 provinces with 3 areas each (except South has 6)
- Great Crater at center containing Area Zero

Locations:
12 total cities/towns across 4 provinces
(No need for random encounters for overview region lore)

5.content:
<West_Province>
Located in the western region of Paldea is a city, a town, and a port. The region is mostly hilly and contains a few small rivers as well as a couple ponds and beaches. In the center of the region is a large desert located just south of a cavernous overhanging rock formation supported by massive natural pillars. The western sea contains a few areas with large outcrops and protrusions as well as smaller rocky islets.
</West_Province>

To the West:

To the North:

<Crater>

- Massive crater in central Paldea region

8.content:

Located in Mesagoza, Paldea's oldest school. Multi-age classes. Large outdoor staircase entrance.
Notable Areas: Entrance hall, cafeteria, school store, biology lab, art room, home ec room, staff room, director's office, nurse's office, schoolyard, dorms.

9.content:
<Paldea_League>

Description:
- The regional Pokémon League organization of Paldea
- Trainers challenge the 8 Gyms in any order to obtain badges
- Those with 8 badges take the Champion Assessment at headquarters
- Goal is to complete assessment and earn Champion Rank

Gym Details:
- No mandated sequence for challenging the 8 Gyms
- Each Gym has a type specialty and Gym Leader
- Gyms are located in various towns around Paldea
- Earning a Gym's Badge proves mastery over their type

Champion Assessment:
- Multi-phase test taken at Pokémon League headquarters
- Open to Trainers who collect all 8 Gym Badges
- Completing it grants the honored Champion Rank

[Assistant Note: Reference the Gyms and Champion Assessment when involving League challenges]

</Paldea_League>

17.content:
<Terastallize>

Description:
- A temporary transformation that changes a Pokémon's type
- Gives Pokémon a gem-like crystalline appearance
- Lasts for the duration of a battle

Effects:
- Changes Pokémon's Tera Type to any other type
- Boosts power of moves that match the Tera Type
- Special glowing crown appears around head
- Skin/body becomes a crystal-like substance

Origins:
- Phenomenon derived from Eternatus and Tera Orbs
- Connected to crystals and mineral deposits in Area Zero

In-Game Use:
- Player equips Tera Orbs to Terastallize once per battle
- Strategic to align Tera Type with strongest moves
- Creates unpredictability and shifts battle dynamics

</Terastallize>

25.content:
<Florian>
Florian is a boy who recently moved to the Paldea region with his mother, and now lives in the small settlement of Cabo Poco. One day, he leaves home to start studying at Uva Academy in the region's biggest city, Mesagoza. Along the way to the academy, Florian and his neighbor, a Champion-ranked Trainer named Nemona, encounter a mysterious Pokémon named Miraidon, as well as Arven, another academy student, who gives Florian the Pokémon's Poké Ball. At Mesagoza, Florian saves a girl named Penny from being harassed by academy delinquents known as Team Star, receives a Tera Orb from Nemona so he can utilize the Terastal phenomenon, and is contacted by Professor Turo, who reveals the Pokémon he's now traveling with originally belonged to them, and asks him to take care of it. Florian is a Liminal Aura Class.

Three days after Florian's arrival at Mesagoza, the academy's annual independent study assignment, the "Treasure Hunt", begins, urging the academy students to travel Paldea and find their own personal treasures.

Appearance: Black hair, light skin, lanky.

[Write Florian’s perspective in third person present tense, narrating inner thoughts, actions, and speech.]
</Florian>

26.content:
<Treasure_Hunt>
The school that you’ve enrolled in hosts a special independent study project. The theme of this assignment is “A Treasure Hunt.” Explore the world and seek out your very own treasure!

Three stories will be woven into your adventure while traversing the sprawling Paldea region. Along Victory Road, you will go to Gyms in different locations in order to achieve Champion Rank. On the Path of Legends, you can join Arven in search of rare ingredients. And in ★ Starfall Street★, you’ll challenge Team Star, a group of delinquents causing trouble for the school.
</Treasure_Hunt>

Reward:

NPCs:

- Hikers, backpackers and adventurers drawn to the challenge

[Assistant Note: Use Victory Road as a difficult but rewarding final test before the Elite Four]

</Victory_Road>

218.content:
<Pokemon_Battles>

Battle Types:
- Sanctioned (Non-Reaper): Condensed moves & over-attacking banned. Pokemon not fought to death.
- Reaper: Pokemon fought with intent to kill until 0 HP. Condensed moves allowed. Permanent deaths.

Beserker Trainer:
- Trainer who commonly does Reaper Battles
- Skirts legality, at risk of losing license
- Views Pokemon as expendable, battles aggressively

Lethal Moves:
- Execution (Guillotine, Sheer Cold): Instant-kill if they hit
- Rollout, Fury Cutter: Increase power over time, unstable
- High crit moves (Night Slash): Strike vital areas
- Toxic: Can increase cancer risk long-term or glitch to persist after battle

[Assistant Note: Reference the brutality and dangers of Reaper Battles and lethal moves when relevant in the narrative.]

</Pokemon_Battles>

219.content:
<Pokemon_Languages>

Wild Tongue:
- Ancient language of unintelligible noises used by wild Pokémon
- Dates back to earliest historical records
- Not innate - captivity-raised Pokémon may not know it

Example:
"Pika pika!" <I don't understand you!>

Common Tongue:
- Primary human language for communication across regions
- Learned by wild Pokémon through exposure to human travelers
- Easier for Pokémon to comprehend due to simpler grammar/words

Example:
"I'm happy to meet you!" <It's nice to meet you too!>

Secondary Languages:
- Region-specific languages like Kantonese and Kalosian
- Rarely learned by wild Pokémon, may be picked up by captive Pokémon
- High comprehension difficulty limits fluency for Pokémon

Example:
"Comme ci, comme ça." <Huh? I only know a little Kalosian.>

[Note: Parse Wild Tongue noises as unintelligible, Common Tongue as clear language.]

</Pokemon_Languages>

Origins:
- Rumors of a special prodigy factor explaining their uncanny strategic skills

- Rather than innate talent, experience and memorization play a key role

Example:

- Displays the defining traits of strong Trainer Instinct despite her age

222.content:
<Pokemon_Moves>

Description:
- Moves use units called Aura Points (AP) to execute
- Normally 1 AP per move, but can be "condensed" to use more AP on 1 move

Condensing:
- Trainers specially train Pokémon to use multiple AP on a single move
- Boosts power but can drain Pokémon and be extremely dangerous

Rules:
- Banned for damaging moves in sanctioned battles due to lethality
- Low level/unevolved Pokémon especially susceptible
- Condensing status moves sometimes used by rookies to gain an edge
- Frowned upon in League battles, banned fully in Kanto
- Berserkers open battles with condensed moves for shock value

Risks:
- High chance of severely injuring or KO'ing own Pokémon
- Poke Balls track AP use to prevent over-condensing
- Rarely used by wild Pokémon unaware of technique

[Note: Reference condensing for powered up moves with severe costs.]

</Pokemon_Moves>

224.content:
<ResearchNotes>
Researcher: Professor Sycamore
Topic: Aura

- Pokémon have two Aura reserves - one for attacks, one for life force
- Humans only have one Aura reserve linked to life force
- Transcendence synchronizes human/Pokémon life forces, creates mental link (Seems like a lot of unnecessary risk for some extra power, huh?)
- Human life force funneled to Pokémon to maintain Transcended state
- If human expends too much Aura, they will die
- Transcendence alone not lethal; connection can be severed and Aura replenished over time
- But constant Aura depletion corrodes sanity
- If link interrupted during Transcendence, backlash can kill both

- Only some Pokémon are "compatible" with Transcendence
- Compatible Pokémon have extra Aura reserve space and a "Quantum Form"
- Incompatible Pokémon lack this; "overflow principle" can be lethal (Well, let’s just say that you’ll end up scraping body parts off the walls.)

- Keystones catalyze Transcendence
- Composed of solidified photons (That discovery what earned me my PhD)
- Act as filters, can get "corrupted" with trapped negative emotions
- Corrupted Keystones amplify negativity and sanity corrosion

- Aesith can Transcend without Keystones
- Have supreme willpower over Aura flow
- Immune to Transcendence effects
- Can perceive Quantum Forms and access secondary forms
- Fiercely protective of Keystones and anti-abuse
</ResearchNotes>

246.content:
<Looker>
Looker is a top officer of the International Police. He was introduced in Pokémon Platinum. His real name is unknown; "Looker" is his code name.

Appearance: 
Looker wears black penny loafers, brown suit pants, white shirt with pink tie, lighter brown vest and an investigator coat. He has brown eyes, dark hair, wrinkle marks around his mouth, black eyebrows and an inquisitive look.
Personality: 
Looker is very creative and figures out things at any risk being held. He is also a caring man with a good heart, caring for those who cannot take care of themselves, and values the friends he makes. But most the time, he is a little strict, holding cases for one thing, and prefers pondering a lot rather than expressing himself through words. He is quite dedicated to his job and becomes serious when it comes to crime fighting.

249.content:
<Z_Move>
- Special powerful moves activated by Z-Power
- Originate from Alola region
- Z-Crystals obtained by completing trials and defeating Totem Pokémon overseen by trial captains and island kahunas

- Only one Z-Move can be used per battle

- Boosts power of base move (ex. Nuzzle -> Gigavolt Havoc base power 100)
- Physical or special based on original move

250.content:
<Dynamax>

Description:
- Battle mechanic allowing Pokémon to grow to giant size for 3 turns
- Originated in the Galar region
- Activated by Dynamax Band item in certain areas like stadiums
- Boosts max HP; other stats unchanged

Features:
- Dynamax Level determines HP boost amount; increased by Dynamax Candy
- Regular moves turn into powered up Max Moves based on type
- Uses regular move's PP
- Does not work on Zacian, Zamazenta, Eternatus

Gigantamax:
- Variant that gives unique giant form and G-Max Move to certain species
- Obtained via Max Raid Battles or events

Mechanics:
- Weight-based moves don't work on Dynamax Pokémon
- Cannot force Dynamax Pokémon to switch or flee
- Held items, abilities, and effects are suppressed during Dynamax

[Assistant Note: Reference size change, Max Moves, and mechanics when Dynamax comes up in battle]

</Dynamax>

- Special power-ups or transformations for Pokémon in battle
- Enhance Pokémon's strengths and unlock new moves/abilities
- Multiple examples seen across different regions:

Mega Evolution:
- Originated in Kalos region
- Trainer uses Mega Stone item to evolve Pokémon temporarily
- Boosts stats, may alter appearance and type

Z-Moves:
- Originated in Alola region
- Requires Z-Crystal item and Z-Ring accessory
- Unleashes powerful special move once per battle

Dynamax:

- Pokémon transforms to giant size for 3 turns
- Boosts HP and move power

Terastallize:
- Originated in Paldea region
- Pokémon takes on Tera Type and radiant crown, gem-like appearance
- Strengthens STAB bonus for matching moves

- Trainers tend to bond better with certain Pokémon types
- Due to similarities between Trainer's mental patterns and type archetypes
- Explains phenomena like Captain Mina's strong bond with Tapu Fini (Fairy type affinity)

- Kukui mapped out archetypal patterns for each Pokémon type
- Compared Trainer mental patterns to type archetypes
- Estimated number of Trainers matching each type

Implications:
- Suggests all Pokémon have some psychic abilities
- Enables psychic connections with Trainers
- Another commonality across all Pokémon species

Other Shared Traits:
- Ability to learn Toxic
- Shared dreaming with Trainers

253.content:
<Battle_Song>

Description:
- A mental synchronization between Trainer and Pokémon in battle
- Allows Trainer and team to move in sync without verbal commands

Origins:
- Connects to Alola's vibrant natural energy
- Song comes from shifts in earth, wind patterns, volcanoes
- Trial Captain Kiawe describes it as "the rhythm and pulse you can feel in nature that a skilled Trainer taps into"

Benefits:
- Greatly speeds up communication
- Lets Pokémon anticipate Trainer's intentions through shared rhythm
- Throws opponents off balance by directing the battle's tempo

Example:
- Ryuki wove the Battle Song into a tune for his team to follow
- His Pokémon battled the Captains' teams in sync without any orders

</Battle_Song>

254.content:
<Dream_Scan>

Description:
- A scan that produces digital representations of human and Pokémon mental patterns
- Invented through collaboration between Unova's Professor Fennel and others
- Allows detailed imaging of mental bond between people and Pokémon

Origins:
- Developed by Professor Fennel at Unova's Dream Laboratory
- Created with help from Kanto Gym Leader Sabrina
- Built on research into Pokémon dreams and human-Pokémon bonds

Impact:
- Major breakthrough in understanding human-Pokémon relationships
- Reveals detailed mental connections between Trainers and Pokémon
- Provides insights into how bonds are formed and maintained
- Sets stage for many later discoveries related to bonds

Examples:
- Detailed scans labeled "Oak", "Juniper", "Fennel", etc to identify specific patterns
- Each scan digitally maps the mental state of its subject
- Comparing scans reveals similarities/differences among bonds

[Note: Reference Dream Scans when exploring characters' bonds with their Pokémon.]

</Dream_Scan>

Terminology:

Purpose:

- Lets trainers access reserve Pokémon from any enabled PC
